plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub with fragrant, showy flowers ranging from white to pink and red, commonly found in Mediterranean and subtropical climates. It blooms profusely in warm climates even in early winter.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round in warm climates, typically spring to fall, extending into winter in mild areas
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, Southern USA, California, and subtropical regions
plants.funFact: Oleander is highly toxic if ingested, but has been used ornamentally for thousands of years due to its vibrant blooms and resilience.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: A popular evergreen shrub admired for its large, ornate flowers that bloom in cooler months, often from late fall to early spring. It thrives in temperate climate zones and is widely cultivated in gardens.
plants.location: East Asia (native), widely cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: The camellia flower was named after Jesuit botanist Georg Kamel, and its petals are used to produce tea in some species closely related to Camellia japonica.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A hardy perennial known for its white to pinkish flowers that bloom in late winter, sometimes starting in December. It is native to mountainous regions of Europe and thrives in shaded garden areas.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is unrelated to roses and has medicinal uses historically, though it is toxic if consumed.

plants.name: Leptospermum scoparium
plants.description: A flowering shrub or small tree native to New Zealand and southeastern Australia, producing small white or pink flowers in late spring to early summer in the Southern Hemisphere, which corresponds to December.
plants.funFact: Manuka flowers are the source of manuka honey, famous worldwide for its unique antibacterial properties.
